title: My vocal range is G2-E5 (female 14) & Its uncormfortable to sing in my upper range what's my voice type? - Quora

response.answer_text: If I were talking to an adult, vocally trained woman, I’d say this is contralto range, and I’d quickly make a wish because they are rare as hell. HOWEVER, you’re a teenager. It’s a misconception that girls’ voice doesn’t drop. It just drops less than boys’ and the period of adjustment is shorter, that’s why women can start singing seriously earlier than men (and why most young singers’ programmes have a limit at 30 for women and at 35 for men). Depending on how low your pre-puberty voice was and when you started undergoing puberty, you may still be adjusting to your new voice. In my conservatory, you couldn’t start taking singing lessons before 16, which is a very sensible limit (that is, until they changed the teacher and the new one decided she didn’t mind having 14-year-olds destroying their voices trying to sing roles ten times their size). As well, without some training, even if it’s just by singing in a choir, it’s very difficult for you to make most of your voice. For what I know, you may have a full octave left to ‘unlock’ once you learn to effectively access your head voice to produce a full sound. So basically, if you were to join a choir I’d put you in the alto section (or 3rd voice in a girls’ choir) but knowing that your range will change over time. And if it turns out you’re a true contralto, great for you! Go ahead, study music and you won’t have employment problems.

With all this, I'm assuming middle c is c4 Judging on how low you can sing, I would say you are an alto. If it's uncomfortable to sing in your upper range, you might want to check your technique. Make sure to have a good posture (feet shoulder width apart and standing/sitting up straight), take deep breaths, drop your jaw, and keep your head center (no tilting forward or back). E5 shouldn't be too strenuous for most girls, so these tips should help. There could also be the case that you have an unusually low voice for a girl, in which case, congrats! If none of these tips help, then take a lesson with a professional vocal coach as they have seen it all. Hope this helps!
